questions.questionText: What is the main purpose of Principal Component Analysis (PCA)?

answerOptions.answerText: To classify data points into categories
To improve model accuracy directly
To reduce the number of features while retaining most variance
To generate regression coefficients

questions.explanation: PCA is a dimensionality reduction technique that transforms data into a lower-dimensional space while preserving as much variance as possible.

questions.questionText: What are principal components in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Original input features
Random projections of the data
New features that are linear combinations of the original ones
Outliers in the dataset

questions.explanation: Principal components are new variables formed as linear combinations of the original features, ordered by the variance they capture.

questions.questionText: Why is PCA used before applying machine learning models?

answerOptions.answerText: To normalize the target variable
To avoid classification bias
To simplify the model and improve computational efficiency
To select the best hyperparameters

questions.explanation: PCA reduces dimensionality, which can simplify the model, speed up training, and reduce overfitting.

questions.questionText: What mathematical technique is often used in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Matrix inversion
Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)
Gradient descent
K-means clustering

questions.explanation: PCA commonly employs Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) to compute the principal components.

questions.questionText: What is the effect of standardizing data before applying PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: It increases model complexity
It ensures all features contribute equally to the PCA
It changes the labels
It increases variance

questions.explanation: Standardization puts features on a similar scale so that PCA does not get biased toward features with larger scales.

questions.questionText: What does 'variance explained' mean in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: The proportion of total variance captured by a principal component
The amount of noise removed from the dataset
The number of original features used
The error in the prediction model

questions.explanation: Variance explained is the proportion of the dataset's variability captured by a principal component.

questions.questionText: How does PCA help reduce computational cost?

answerOptions.answerText: By increasing the number of features
By reducing the number of dimensions while retaining key information
By removing outliers
By normalizing the data

questions.explanation: PCA reduces the number of features, thereby lowering the computational resources required.

questions.questionText: In PCA, what does each principal component represent?

answerOptions.answerText: An original feature
A new variable that is a linear combination of original features
A raw measurement
A noise element in the data

questions.explanation: Each principal component is a new feature derived from a linear combination of original features.

questions.questionText: How is the percentage of total variation captured by a principal component determined?

answerOptions.answerText: By calculating the sum of all eigenvalues
By dividing the eigenvalue of the component by the sum of all eigenvalues
By computing the squared loadings
By normalizing the data

questions.explanation: The eigenvalue of a principal component divided by the total sum of eigenvalues gives the proportion of variance explained by that component.

questions.questionText: Why is PCA considered an unsupervised learning technique?

answerOptions.answerText: Because it uses labels to reduce dimensions
Because it does not use any output labels to transform the data
Because it clusters data points
Because it uses regression for dimensionality reduction

questions.explanation: PCA is unsupervised as it only analyzes the input features without any reference to output labels.

questions.questionText: What does a scree plot display in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: The relationship between two features
The eigenvalues associated with each principal component
The raw data distribution
The modelâ€™s prediction accuracy

questions.explanation: A scree plot shows the eigenvalues of principal components, helping determine the number of components to retain.

questions.questionText: How do you decide the number of principal components to keep?

answerOptions.answerText: By keeping all components regardless of variance
By selecting the components that capture a high percentage of total variance, often 80-95%
By choosing the first two components only
By selecting the components with the smallest eigenvalues

questions.explanation: The number of components is usually chosen based on a threshold of variance explained, such as 80% to 95%.

questions.questionText: What role do eigenvalues play in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: They represent the direction of maximum variance
They indicate the importance of each principal component
They are used to scale the data
They eliminate noise from the data

questions.explanation: Eigenvalues indicate how much variance is captured by each principal component, reflecting its importance.

questions.questionText: What is the relationship between eigenvalues and variance explained in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Eigenvalues are inversely proportional to variance explained
Higher eigenvalues correspond to greater variance explained
Eigenvalues do not affect variance
Variance explained is the square of the eigenvalue

questions.explanation: Higher eigenvalues mean that the corresponding principal component captures a larger portion of the total variance.

questions.questionText: How does PCA affect noise in the dataset?

answerOptions.answerText: It increases the noise
It often removes noise by discarding components with very low variance
It retains most of the noise in the first components
It converts noise into useful signals

questions.explanation: By discarding components that explain little variance (often attributed to noise), PCA can help reduce noise in the dataset.

questions.questionText: Why is standardization important before applying PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: It reduces the number of features
It ensures all features contribute equally regardless of their scales
It increases the variance
It improves the correlation between features

questions.explanation: Standardizing the data prevents features with larger scales from dominating the PCA results.

questions.questionText: What is a major drawback of PCA when applied to non-linear data?

answerOptions.answerText: It removes all outliers
It may not capture complex, non-linear relationships
It always overfits
It increases dimensionality

questions.explanation: PCA is a linear technique and can struggle to capture non-linear relationships in the data.

questions.questionText: How is PCA different from feature selection methods?

answerOptions.answerText: PCA selects a subset of the original features
PCA creates new features that are linear combinations of the original ones
Feature selection reduces overfitting, PCA does not
There is no difference between PCA and feature selection

questions.explanation: Feature selection chooses a subset of original features, while PCA generates new, uncorrelated features (principal components) from linear combinations of the original features.

questions.questionText: Which business application can benefit from PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Stock price prediction
Customer segmentation by reducing high-dimensional data
Real-time fraud detection
Sentiment analysis of text

questions.explanation: PCA is commonly used in customer segmentation to simplify high-dimensional data into fewer components that capture essential behavior.

questions.questionText: If PCA reduces a dataset from 12 dimensions to 3 dimensions with 75% variance explained, what does that mean?

answerOptions.answerText: 3 dimensions capture 75% of the original data's variability
The data now has 75% more features
75% of the data is lost
The model is overfitting

questions.explanation: It means that 3 principal components capture 75% of the total variability in the original 12-dimensional dataset.

questions.questionText: How are principal components ordered in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Randomly
By the order of original features
By decreasing amount of variance they capture
By increasing eigenvalue

questions.explanation: Principal components are ordered such that the first component captures the most variance, and each subsequent component captures progressively less.

questions.questionText: What is the significance of the first principal component in PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: It is the least important
It captures the highest variance
It is always equal to the sum of the remaining components
It is used to normalize the data

questions.explanation: The first principal component is the most significant, capturing the largest portion of the variance in the data.

questions.questionText: What does 'orthogonality' mean in the context of PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Principal components are correlated
Principal components are independent and perpendicular to each other
Principal components are always positive
Principal components are clustered together

questions.explanation: Orthogonality in PCA means that the principal components are uncorrelated with each other; they are mathematically perpendicular in the feature space.

questions.questionText: How does PCA assist in visualizing high-dimensional data?

answerOptions.answerText: By converting data into a 3D scatter plot
By reducing the dimensions to 2 or 3 principal components
By increasing the number of features for visualization
By clustering data points

questions.explanation: Reducing dimensions to 2 or 3 principal components allows for effective visualization of the data in scatter plots.

questions.questionText: Which type of plot is commonly used to help decide the number of principal components to retain?

answerOptions.answerText: Box plot
Scree plot
Histogram
Scatter plot

questions.explanation: A scree plot displays the eigenvalues associated with each principal component and helps to identify the 'elbow' where additional components contribute little extra variance.

questions.questionText: What is the impact of not standardizing your data before applying PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: Features with larger scales dominate the results
It has no impact
It always improves the quality of PCA
It reduces computation time significantly

questions.explanation: Without standardization, features with larger scales can dominate the principal components, which distorts the analysis.

questions.questionText: What is an eigenvector in the context of PCA?

answerOptions.answerText: A scalar value representing the weight of a feature
A vector that defines the direction of a principal component
A randomly generated vector
A vector representing the error term

questions.explanation: In PCA, an eigenvector indicates the direction along which the data is most spread out, forming the basis of a principal component.

questions.questionText: Why might one choose to use PCA even if it slightly reduces model accuracy?

answerOptions.answerText: To improve interpretability and reduce overfitting
Because PCA always increases accuracy
To eliminate all noise
To reduce training time to zero

questions.explanation: PCA simplifies the model and can help reduce overfitting, enhancing interpretability even if there's a small trade-off in accuracy.

questions.questionText: What is the main benefit of dimensionality reduction through PCA in machine learning pipelines?

answerOptions.answerText: It increases the number of features
It reduces computational cost and mitigates the curse of dimensionality
It always improves prediction accuracy
It changes the data labels

questions.explanation: Reducing dimensions helps lower computational requirements and can improve a modelâ€™s performance by alleviating issues related to high-dimensional data.

questions.questionText: How does PCA address the problem of multicollinearity?

answerOptions.answerText: It increases the correlation between features
It transforms correlated features into uncorrelated principal components
It removes one of each pair of correlated features
It does not address multicollinearity

questions.explanation: PCA transforms the original features into a new set of uncorrelated components, effectively dealing with multicollinearity.
